currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each ot

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the intern

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online g

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance. But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have b

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other acc

These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of persona

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or ri

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance. In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing

What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across scr

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will nn

We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of c

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymor

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore

These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won't develop a social sense

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won't develop a social sense of friendship with kids o

People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won't develop a social sense of friendship with kids outside the home anymore

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won't develop a social sense of friendship with kids outside the home anymore, and teachers won't feel as dedicated to their s

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, all the screen time for online schools, online work from home or remote work it going to have a very bad impact on us socially. Sooner or later people will become anti-social. People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

We have seen this in the development of gaming for instance.  What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs). These friends were not complete strangers. Sure, there was fun loving jibbing each other sometimes, but no one felt like they were really under personal attack.

Today if you play a game online, you stay at home and connect your PC or console to the internet and join an online game. Gamers have become toxic to each other across because there is no longer a sense of personal connectedness or friendship at all. It's easy to call someone a loser when there is no consequences for said action.

The same thing will take place across screens for work and school as time goes by. People will not feel that sense of comradery at work anymore. Kids won't develop a social sense of friendship with kids outside the home anymore, and teachers won't feel as dedicated to their students or bosses to the

People will forget how to deal with others in person. People will lose their patience. We will develop problems communicating with others due to the mostly the loss of personal connection with others.

What seems like a long time ago, if you wanted to play a multiplayer game, you had multiple controllers, food, snacks, drinks, and your friends would come over to your house to play (or you would go to theirs).
